commentBody:
Nice theme with the one rebus becoming the three sets of circled squares, along with the two theme answers.

The fill was decent also, but this was slightly too easy for a Wednesday puzzle. 

8/10.
Felt more like a Tuesday puzzle. Nothing too tricky or obscure.

I really liked the way the STAR exploded bigger and bigger. It would have been fun if the solved puzzle had been animated--bright orange flames or something similar. The symmetry of STARBURST and MAKEITPOP was also very nice.
Loved this one, very fun little theme.

I HADABLAST with this breezy puzzle, although I was a bit disappointed that all the circles weren‚Äôt  rebuses. It would have been quite a feat of construction, however, to have rebuses in the cluster of four touching circles.
Loved it.
This was a stunning debut. I absolutely loved the star exploding across the grid and the echo of related answers like ad astra, starburst, and make it pop. Gold star for this one. More please.
Nice non-Thursday, non-Sunday rebus ü§ì
Great debut, Evan!  And kudos to Jeffrey for recognizing your talent and getting you hooked on crosswords. Very clever and fun puzzle to solve.

Probably the best application of a rebus crossword I've ever seen.  Great stuff.

I had one squared circle remaining, having noted the theme and the expanding s-t-a-rs.  I still didn't suspect a rebus - not a single other square needed it so why would I - and then the duh moment kicked in, finally letting me solve the upper left corner clues and beautifully finishing (or starting) the theme progression.

Excellent.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler) 


That was a very satisfying finish.  Excellent.
Minor quibble: an eagle is not a good golf score, it's a great score. It means two under par for the hole.
very clever and fun puzzle
Maybe a bit of a cautinary tale about involving current events in the crossword, but wince the fall of the Assas regime most people would say SYRIA's flag has three red stars, not two green ones.

Loved this! It was an ingenious puzzle, not just for the one single rebus waiting for the solver's aha moment, but also for the inclusion of AD ASTRA and NEIL DeGrasse Tyson, both so pertinent to to the SUPERNOVA theme. (If I were him, I would be flattered not just to be in the NYT xword, but to be alongside a topic that speaks to me.) For the musical accompaniment, of course there's only one song that comes to mind... https://youtu.be/tI-5uv4wryI?si=90kEOC5Yo19g3d3Y Thank you, Messieurs, and congratulations to Evan on a debut that was sweet and delicious as a STARBURST melting in the mouth!

Aw, man, I put the S in the rebus circle at the very end before I realized it was a rebus. :)
Nevertheless, a fun puzzle to solve.

Not me having AR in the center of the answer for "That really stinks!" and filling in a F and T ...

Great puzzle and loved the novel theme execution.
Whelp.  That was fun.
Really fun solve and I enjoyed the rebus. Nice Wednesday where everything came together pretty smoothly but with enough twists to be satisfying. Congrats on your debut!
That was fun and I guess that I won't be the only one who filled the rebus last. It didn't make sense till it did.
satisfying. loved the visual wordplay; clever without reaching
Maybe my favorite Wednesday puzzle ever.
Surprise rebus twist at the end! What a fun and clever Wednesday puzzle with which to end the day. Thank you, Evan and Jeffrey!

Proud to have landed a Wednesday best on this one. Huge satisfaction earning a clean solve with a solo rebus for my final square filled.

Great puzzle. Thanks, Evan Park and Jefferey Martinovic

How delightful and serendipitous to have this puzzle land today, after just witnessing the safe return of the space station astronauts. 

Brilliant execution of a stellar theme!

Congratulations to the constructors, and especially to Evan on his debut.
What does 19A mean? Is there a way to get an explainer without spoilers for everyone else?

Well, I can't seem to get anything past the emus, so I'll just write an ultra abbreviated version with a small number of words, so I can tell which one the emus don't like *today*.

Puzzle   good.       Liked it.

Love stars.

"Will we finally see a star explode today?"
"You nova know!"

("Can't you ever be Sirius?")
Enjoyed the puzzle today. Tricky rebus!
Good Wednesday puzzle. Not too easy, not too hard. Fun with that sneaky rebus.
Had a blast. I rule.
OHME?  No. Just no.
Photo (& caption) heading today's comments is pretty d(ough)roll
Another editing error within a few months - Syria's flag has been changed by the interim Constitution. It features three red stars. The Assad regime's flag was the one with the two green stars.
This puzzle was awesome! Loved it. Was a satisfying solve.
Can someone explain what RESEA means in the context of the clue? I know what RESEA the agency is but not understanding how that relates to the clue. Thanks!

Thank you, that was fun! I didn‚Äôt get the rebus, but was glad that the app rewarded me with a win when I plugged in just the S. It was only when I got here that I saw the exploding star and understood what was going on. I didn‚Äôt know there was such a thing as a single rebus problem ‚Äì until now! My mind just went supernova‚Ä¶

Thoroughly enjoyed every second of this solve, and loved the column just as equally. Filled the puzzle completely and wasn‚Äôt met with the music until I discovered, OH My, one typo. 

Sam, I couldn‚Äôt agree more with your stance on space; yes, we are a mere speck in the grand scheme of it all, but what a wonderful idea that can lend itself to be. 

Happy Wednesday everyone! Do emus have humps?

Strands Thread:

Strands #381
‚ÄúUpright and grand‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button.

I do not understand the instructions provided in today‚Äôs notes to enter more than one letter in a square. I am using my IPhone to do the puzzle so I used the instruction for IOS by pressing on the appropriate square . Nothing happened‚Ä¶??                               

Can I ask for help with this? How does one enter more than one letter for a rebus? 

Thank you!
Solving the rebus early made me overthink every other circled square. Good one, puzzle creators! And congrats on a stellar debut.

Wow!  My brain must work differently than most other people's.  I got the star rebus immediately, and then when I got to Starburst at 10 down, it became obvious what was going on with the other circled squares.  Can a square be circled?

Great puzzle.  Also loved how they sneaked Sulu in too.

Wow. Quite an amazing puzzle. Typical Wednesday workout for me, and then... the STAR rebus in RESTAREA was the last thing I filled in, and it wasn't until then that I really parsed the other sets of circled squares. Just can't even imagine what it takes to put together something like this, with both the restrictions of the theme square entries and - managing to do that synchronously form upper left to lower right. Just - Wow. 

And... a VERY unusual puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

Evan and Jeffrey packed a lot of fun into one small grid. 

Besides the very cool expanding STAR, they gave us HAD A BLAST, SUPER NOVA, STAR BURST, MAKE IT POP, NEIL deGrasse Tyson, the EAGLE has landed and AD ASTRA.  

Then they threw in a rebus as a final treat.  

I'm looking forward to more from these two.
I'm quite literally 2 mins into the crossword so trying not to look at any other comments just in case, but I have to say I let out a audible 'Oh that's good' in the break room when I got the theme.

Well, I guess I‚Äôm the only one but I thought it was misleading to have only one rebus.  Didn‚Äôt even think the one slot was a rebus because none of the others were. All you superior puzzle solvers can start beating up on me now.

What a delightfully deceptive day!

Was fortunate to have moved past 
the NE with a couple unfilled squares,
so the single S and T in the middle 
we‚Äôre already apparent.

But candy-coated cleverness abounds!

Loved it.

Been getting a bit pummeled by
Life, so I‚Äôve missed you all for a few days.

Very, very happy to be back!

‚≠êÔ∏è

When the rebus is the same in each direction, I guess you only need one instance of it, on iOS at least?  I had STAR/STAR and S/S, knowing it was ‚Äúrest area‚Äù and ‚Äúlost arts‚Äù but I did not get the solve until only entering ‚ÄúSTAR‚Äù.
Who do I email about my crossword streak? I‚Äôve been completing my crosswords every day for over 550 days and today it says I‚Äôm on day 3 of a streak.
The clue for 4 across in the Mini today was incorrect. "Halloween costume that often includes suspenders and a fake mustache" - it's not suspenders, it's overalls.
EAGLE is not a ‚Äúgood‚Äù golf score (or a good Super Bowl champ). It is totally awesome.
Cute but easy!

I‚Äôve shared thoughts about visual accessibility before. This is basic stuff for web/app designers. In today‚Äôs puzzle, the circled letters are essential to completing the grid and I can‚Äôt see them. 

In dark mode, the circled squares are virtually invisible. Personally, I use dark mode because I do the puzzle when it comes out at night and I like to minimize my light exposure, but there are people who use dark mode to compensate for a visual impairment. It is a valuable accessibility feature. 

This is easy to fix. Make the circles yellow in dark mode so that they are visible. If you would like to replicate what I see, solve today‚Äôs puzzle on an iPhone 15 pro max with the screen brightness almost all the way down and the puzzle set to dark mode. There are other visual accessibility issues with your app, like how difficult it is to see the numbers, but this is a really easy one to fix, so it‚Äôs a great place to start. 

Thank you,
Torey Adler - avid solver, currently on an 893 day streak.
I loved this one!
As a rebus lover I‚Äôm quite disappointed that I didn‚Äôt see it, only noticed the growing STARS.  Very impressive debut and definitely looking forward to more from Evan and Jeffrey.

One of these days I'll learn not to use a red card word from the puzzle in my comment (27A).  See that a number of other comments are in a similar status.  

Wanted to say what a great puzzle and congrats on Evan's debut.

The only nit I want to pick is that I am of the belief that the Mini Crossword should not have an identical (or near identical) clue and answer as the Full Sized Crossword. It just doesn't seem right, but alas what can I do but state my dissatisfaction and hope the powers that be allow it to be AIRED beyond this little text box I'm typing in.

I started in the NW and got the rebus right away. I thought I had the theme nailed, but then realized I hadn‚Äôt quite figured it out. I got an inkling when I encountered 36D because the only answer is ASIA and its sister answer had to be TERSE (I don‚Äôt think I have ever heard this word uttered yet I know it well.) When STARBURST presented itself, all became clear and I was able to go back and fill in the gaps. 

Some trivia new to me. Until I got the gimmick I thought I might be lost in space! But once I got it, the cross fill came to the rescue nicely and got me back in orbit.

Evan and Jeffrey, thanks for a celestial puzzle!
Really cute. Great job. Hope you guys had fun and bring more like it.

You know what‚Äôs going to keep me up at night?
Not a ‚Äúbed seat‚Äù.
Not a ‚Äúbed spat‚Äù.
No. Just the fact that somehow seeing KeAUS first, and shrugging at a weird name for an unknown brother, somehow blinded me to the obviously better bed letter.

(And an outside inside reference: are those invasive plants self-pollinating? Just being lemon persnickety ;)
I thoroughly enjoyed the little animations on past rebuses and was a little disappointed not to see one here. Great puzzle though!

Oh, man, the things you can do in crosswords!

That visual of the supernova‚Äôs explosion traveling through the grid is remarkable to look at.  It‚Äôs also a remarkable idea to have thought up, and while I‚Äôm on ‚Äúremarkable‚Äù, those 13 circles with letters in them make that entire NW to SE sash remarkably hard to cleanly fill, and look how well Evan and Jeffrey did!

That alone makes this puzzle CLASS A.  But they didn‚Äôt stop there.  They saturated the grid with outer space echoes from the four longest answers to AD ASTRA, NEIL (the astrophysicist), and SULU (as in ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù).

Then came a marvelous solving moment for me, when I looked more closely at the circled letters, saw the expanding stars, and, with an explosive ‚ÄúAha!‚Äù, figured out the surprise single rebus.

A Crosslandia peak moment set in grid beauty?  What an outing! I loved this.  Evan, congratulations on your NYT debut, and Jeffrey, congratulations on your tenth, and to both of you, enthusiastic thumbs up.  Thank you!

I 17A. with the puzzle! But on at least one clue I couldn't 34D.
Two cute additions to the theme!

This puzzle was really cool.  Since Thursday puzzles are known to be tricky, having this puzzle on a Wednesday is an excellent way to introduce a new solver to the rebus function since you can see the letters in STAR disperse throughout the grid.
It was also neat how they worked in a few other space-related entries.  Awesome job -- really enjoyable solve :)
Excellent job Evan and Jeffrey. And thanks for the well placed rebus -- it made the puzzle (and my day)!

A nice Wednesday puzzle, with an interesting theme, an usual symmetry (across the NW-SE diagonal) and even a rebus!

The symmetrically placed HADABLAST and MAKEITPOP were cute, and the same for SUPERNOVA and STARBURST.

Unfortunately, ADASTRA was symmetrically paired with BEDSLAT, which detracted just a bit from this puzzle's stellar theme. Both literally and figuratively. 

This one was on my wavelength, and I was done in barely ten minutes.
Thanks for the fun puzzle from Canada!! We still love you :)

My ‚Äúcomplaint‚Äù is that I was allowed to put an ‚Äús‚Äù into the first circle, my last fill for gold.  ‚ÄúWhat is a resea,‚Äù said I.  If you have to think ‚Äúrebus‚Äù then you should have to place a rebus!  But I‚Äôll take it.

I turned off the timer on the crossword settings today and I think that was the nicest solve for me in a while. I'm sure that feature is probably well known here.

I've never really been one for speed solving, but I would see the time tick up and I felt like I had to go faster nonetheless. I'd go to the hints sooner. I'd get frustrated if my Sunday took me longer than usual. I wouldn't even pause to sip my tea or think about my day without exiting the game.

I never really noticed that it had changed the way I play so much.

Anyway, this was a wonderful puzzle! It took me a minute in the NW to figure out what I needed to do. Very clever.

Oh you GOT me with that ONE rebus! Tricky!

Fun solve anyway.

One of the very few times I‚Äôve been stumped by a Wednesday puzzle.  Which is why this comment is going to sound like sour grapes (because it is).  I was doomed by the answer ‚Äúbed slats‚Äù.  IMHO ‚Äúbed seats‚Äù is the far better answer, fitting in it at least as well, if not better than, the answer used by the constructor.  A slat is hardly unique to a bed.  There is no need to refer to it as a bed slat, even if it is a slat.  Of course, knowing nothing about the Lemony Snicket siblings is what really did me in.

That gripe aside, I was truly star-struck when I realized the brilliance of the exploding S, T, A, R.  It made my failure in the SE corner all the more irritating.  Kudos to the constructors!

1 rebus is 1 too many on a Wednesday: Just sayin.

Otherwise got it done.

Thanks lads, a fun solve.

This was not a difficult puzzle except where it WAS.
The little SE corner was a mess.  Lemony Snicket came along after our kids were in college, and I was no longer teaching junior high special ed; (I wd for sure have read at least one out loud...)
BED something keeping me up?
Good golf score?  (I'm with Twain re golf)
Elsewhere:
People who get my letters use the term at 3D...

The fault, dear Solver, is not in our puzzles...
Also:
The STARs shall fade away...

Another Wednesday POY nominee for me (third one this year!). I absolutely loved everything about this puzzle ‚Ä¶ no lookups, solving it five minutes better than my average, the visual portrayal of the SUPERNOVA, the sneaky rebus (which I got right away), the additional space-themed answers, and one of the best clues I‚Äôve seen all year: 59D, [Invasive plant?]. What a stunning debut! Gold star üåü to the constructors! I hope to see more of your puzzles! I‚Äôm starting to like Wednesday puzzles!

Do emus give out gold stars? ‚≠êÔ∏è

If it's true that no one expects the Spanish Inquisition, then certainly nobody expects a puzzle with only ONE rebus square in it. Got the answer almost  by accident and then came to enjoy what the setter had done.

A Star is Born!

The puzzle was very nice, but filling in that last square at the very end (you know which square it was) was *fantastic*. Having one trick square could be too subtle, but the rest of the theme really pointed the way. Great job!
I thought Wednesday puzzles were supposed to be free from Rebus nonsense, that those only show up in Thursday and Sunday puzzles. Is that not the case?
Nice little bonus rebus! Just wish there had been a STARBURST animation as a reward for solving this puzzle (I know, I know, solving is its own reward ;)
Gold stars for Evan and Jeffery!
Wow, that was the worst puzzle I've ever played. What a waste. Making a puzzle a challenge shouldn't mean randomly changing rules for how to fill them in.

A rebus!!!
And on a Wednesday!
What are we to do???

Relax and enjoy a wonderfully clever puzzle.

Thanks, Evan Park and Jeffrey Martinovic, and congratulations on your debut, Evan!
I'm a firm Rebus-Hater but this puzzle was great
On line puzzle didn‚Äôt make me enter a rebus. It accepted an ‚ÄòS‚Äô. Doesn‚Äôt seem right.
Whenever I see a rebus, I race to the comments section to defend their honour. I love rebuses! Especially when they're surprises!
She-devil? Sho' nuff??
Fun as always. 30 Down: should be dies as in dies irae.  Diem is the accusative.

I am a total sucker for anything astronomical.  And this was a really great example of creativity.

So, BIG thumbs up from my corner.
The "teaser reveal" clue at 59A jumped out so then focused on the remnant circles.   Clever and fun theme very well executed with some DARN clever cluing.  Many thanks.
Across the universe tonight you can hear the sound of rebus haters heads explode.

Love the theme and execution. Loved all the star references. 
Bonus - it was a nice coincidence that the astronauts came back last evening.
‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

What Lewis said! Glad to see so much positive feedback for this very clever puzzle. For me, the ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment filling in the one rebus square just felt more fun than usual. Thanks Evan and Jeffrey!

Great puzzle ruined by publishing it on a Wednesday. Quit doing this, NYT! It‚Äôs not fair to the players or the constructors. This puzzle was sufficiently difficult to be Thursday worthy. Why irritate a large percentage of your subscribers by forcing it on a Wednesday?!

Someday you will find me, caught beneath the landslide
In a champagne SUPERNOVA in the sky...

...but not today. Loved the gimmick, and spotted the rebus very quickly.

I love it when there's a little trick I didn't see coming and thought the STAR rebus was perfect. The STARBURST theme wouldn't have worked as well without it. 

Except for three years in Japan, I've lived in California my entire life and would never have guessed Fresno is its most populous inland city. I would have said San Jose, which is at least 25 miles from the coast. Google agrees that the correct answer is Fresno but when I query if San Jose is a coastal city Google says no, it is inland.
Really great puzzle! Unsure about 32A‚Ä¶ is that a regional thing?

Really had fun with this. Rebus lovers unite! My main issue was that some of the cluing and fill was reaching to much. OH ME is usually combined with OH MY. Never heard anyone say OH ME in this way. Cluing for IS IT was also a little clunky. A TASER is not really a stun gun. It definitely stuns, but a stun gun is a totally different device. Maybe there should be a question mark there. BROODS and FRETS are not synonymous in my book, former is more depressive and latter is more anxious. ENDS IT could‚Äôve also used a better clue. But everything else works and bravo with the theme!

Very enjoyable! At the end, it seemed like STAR should go in the upper left Rebus but at first I was thinking Restaurant before REST AREA. And before that I thought Rest Stop spilled into the other squares. A good one!
PS and at the beginning I thought maybe the rebus was STST to make Rest Stop.
Sadly I did not know AFLAC. (TIL) so no star for me on this star of a puzzle. Congrats on a great puzzle.
Have never heard anyone exclaim 'OH ME' either in real life or in media or literature. 'OH MY' is a common exclamation that fits the meaning of the clue, though.

What a fun puzzle! The number of circle squares warned of many possible rebi, but I just kept plugging along. It worked out fine, with some bumps along the way (I filled in a number of wrong words at the beginning). The theme and the science-related clues were wonderful. I left the one actual rebus square blank till the end, looked at the pattern of the SUPERNOVA stars, then -- Boom! (So to speak.)

Bed SLAT made me laugh out loud. It was almost a cryptic clue, where the solver has to think very literally and imaginatively at the same time.

How on (or off) Earth do the two constructors do all their extracurricular activities, construct a NYT-worthy puzzle, and keep up their marks at Western? This just goes to show that Western students are... not dummies.

Bravi! More from this team, please. Go Canada!

Wasted two minutes in lower right corner, mostly because the clue ‚ÄúGood golf score‚Äù for 55-Down was poorly phrased. 

Likewise, the clue and answer for 58-Across might be OK in the minds of the puzzle constructor or editor, but it is an LA Times-quality entry in the NYT puzzle - in other words, pretty crappy. 

Seeing that in the lower right corner means cramming it in to get the theme. 

The NYT used to be better than that.
Clever puzzle, but I believe the current Syrian flag (since Assad fell) has three red stars in the middle, not two green stars, despite what the emoji shows. üá∏üáæ

Do we put in our two cents‚Äô worth about Connections here as well as the usual emu commentary?  If so, I would like to point out that ‚Äúplancha‚Äù is Spanish, though the French equivalent is close.  Now Ancona will tell me they us3 a la plancha at  Le Cirque or something.
What a class A blast I had solving this stellar puzzle! A rebus, a visual, and all that theme fill made this puzzle SUPER fun!

The following is now at the end of the Wordplay column.

A correction was made on March 19, 2025: An earlier version of today‚Äôs Mini Crossword contained a clue that incorrectly suggested that Mario, the video game character, wears suspenders. He wears overalls.

Congrats on your debut, Evan. You and Jeffrey make a great team and I can‚Äôt wait to see more of your puzzles in future. This was so much fun to figure out, such an unusual and clever theme. I hope you can ignore the curmudgeonly comments from a few people who perhaps are having a bad day. This will go down as one of my absolute favorites of the year. 
I had a bad night‚Äôs sleep and was a little grumpy when I started doing my puzzles this morning, but this gem put a smile on my face. üòä
oh. a rebus. neat.
I had the most trouble with the lower right quadrant!

I‚Äôm just here for the rebus angst.
My misspent childhood eating candy solved this puzzle for me

Knowing OTIS Reading and SHE devil was enough for the candy id
And gave me 13 free squares. :)
I spent a fun semester of law school at the Univeristy of Western Ontario. it it gave me a little jolt of alumnal pride to the see that the puzzle constructors are from the school.

The northwest corner stumped me, but I appreciated the trick when I finally gave up and read the column. It seemed like a fair surprise rebus, considering how long I'd spent wondering if the first circle needed to be an S or if it could be any of S, T, A, or R! A very clever solution.

I'm usually terrible at recalling names, so I was amazed to pull KLAUS out of my memory banks immediately, ~2 decades after last reading A Series of Unfortunate Events! 

The clue that vexed me the most was ATRIA -- it was the first thing I thought of after solving only the final A, but I spent quite a bit of time arguing with myself over whether an atrium is a courtyard. Apparently it can be used to mean an open-air space -- another learning from a crossword!

Brilliant puzzle. Absolutely loved it. Lots of guessing on my part that either paid off nicely or worked out on the crosses, and it took me a hot second at the end to find my error in SULe/YeP (having never seen Star Trek), but I still really enjoyed this one.

Nice debut, Evan! You and Jeffrey make a good team.

No major problems other than the occasional typo, but I did leave 1A blank for a while until the crosses made the decision for me. Figured out the rebus fairly early‚Äîsolving 10D gave me a nice clue to that, as well as how the other circles were going to get filled.

Fun puzzle‚Äîthanks, guys! Hope to see more from you.
So where‚Äôs the supernova graphic? All that for just the annoying jingle? Sad.
I feel this week's puzzles have been stellar! I have enjoyed each and every one, amazed beyond my usual thus far. I am happy to read how many solvers loved today's rebus, which was quite effective!

Moving to next-level solving may involve

taking a moment when the puzzle first appears
to consider the empty grid on its own, that is, without reading any clues (or titles or author credits, for that matter).

Elements to be taken in might include

Is it the expected 15x15 (or on Sunday, 21x21) or are the dimensions unusual?

Is the symmetry the usual rotational symmetry or is it hyper-symmetrical or mirror symmetrical; if mirrored, is it the very rare diagonal line of symmetry (as today‚Äôs is)?

Are there oddities such as stranded squares, two square answers, circles, etc.? Where are they?

Do the black squares form a shape (best evaluated at a distance)?

Taking just a few seconds to ponder these things can help take your solving game up a notch. It only takes a little patience!
Nice one. Theme is cute and not too much random trivia. Thanks!
Is there a term for Crossword entries that need to be launched into the sun? I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve heard anyone say I RULE in, like, 30 years.

Hah!  So there I was, fixing a snack, thinking what a good week of puzzles it's been so far, when suddenly a song I haven't thought about in forever started playing in my head, and then it hit me why.

My brain must have thinking since yesterday what might be a good alternative answer to yesterday's theme -- PARTY FOWL -- because the song playing in my head was "Rockin' Robin"!

Fun puzzle. I filled in DIEs (nominative case) instead of DIEM (accusative) without hesitation and without reading the cross then it took several minutes to spot my error. Either answer agrees with the clue since "day" is the same in either case in English -- I just need to slow down!

A lot of these comments and replies come from experienced crossworders. As someone new to a NYT Games subscription and thus to NYT crosswords themselves, it has been a frustrating learning experience. It is one thing to learn the tricks of these creators, such as today's rebus. But it is another to have to do so in the company of messy clues, i.e. poor translations, arguable phrases, and haphazard use of the question mark protocol (shall we say). I am stuck in the woods for awhile with no access to paper crosswords, and had hoped these would tip more towards exciting and engaging than frustrating and sloppy. But I'm sure one day I'll become a crossword elitist like the other commenters, possibly even having another go at the cryptics, sigh.

"Are the stars out tonight?
I don't know if it's cloudy or bright,
'cause I only have eyes for" clues.

Fun puzzle
Fun one! I love Starbursts, and, having lived here for 60 years, I can definitely attest to Fresno being the most populous inland California city.

This was an excellent puzzle, alas, I was too tired and rushed to fully enjoy it:-(
Greetings to London!

Rebus on Wednesdays now too? Is any day safe for just a normal, one letter per square puzzle anymore? Keep the gimmicks to Thursday. 

That being said, this was alright for a rebus and satisfying enough to complete. Appropriate difficulty for a Wednesday, I just loathe rebus puzzles personally
Fantastic Wednesday puzzle. Absolute blast to solve.

This was a really fun puzzle with a clever theme! I went through it fairly quickly but then stalled out with only one square left to fill. You know the one.

I stared at that Northwest box with just the one empty circle for minutes, demanding it reveal its secrets to me, certain there was no letter that could go in that circle that would complete the across and down. 

And it was all that was left of the puzzle. That one devious little circle...

I couldn't get it, I couldn't get it, I couldn't get it, I got it!!!! I got it!!! Huzzah!!! IRULE!!

I love the ahas of crossword puzzling!!

And a one square rebus, I love it

I see no fault in these stars!
I'll forgive the "rebus on Wednesday" because the puzzle itself was so sweet.
Rebus puzzles fill me with rage.
I need a little help understanding how this puzzle depicts a supernova visually.

This puzzle was superb! I got the theme fairly easily, and was able to get the few unknowns on crosses. 

Favorite clue? Invasive plant? As a fan of espionage novels, it tickled me pink!

Great puzzle! The timing was difficult for me, as I thought of the Supernova festival and documentary, having seen the film "October 8" today. Grateful to have amazing crosswords as a partial escape from a cruel world.
What fun! Loved it. Very nice.

I figured out the star theme & super nova, but it took me a while to see the rebus on a Wednesday. What fun when I got it!

19A?  ITT?  There was a TV show in the sixties called the Addams Family, based on a famous New Yorker cartoonist who did mock horror comics.

Of the strange and goofy members of the family, one of them was a three or four foot stack of hair that ran around and was called "cousin Itt".  It never spoke as far as I know.

@Francis 

There have also been several successful movies and other media (cartoons, the recent Wednesday series starting Itt Girl Ortega).  Raul Julia was memorable, even if he was basically just channeling John Astin's work on the TV show.

Also, at least in the original show Cousin Itt burbled like a helium hamster....

Also, day in ancient Rome (in the nominative case, which is the default unless otherwise indicated) was DIEs, and DIEM is the form in another case. Declension is a thing in Latin...

@Andrzej I never learned Latin, though I know a little about cases via my wife and a few Latin ohrases. 

So my brain started with DIEs (from dies irae) and then moved to DIEM (from per diem). Fortunately I didn't need to know examples of the other cases!
@Andrzej Eh. Even in the accusative, a day is still a day. It was one of those clues that you had to figure out contextually.

@Jaze 

It may seem like that to somebody whose language does not involve declension. Mine does. It would never be OK in Polish to ask for a form of a noun in a specific case without indicating it. Take the word "syn" (son):

Syn
Syna 
Synowi
Syna
Synem 
Synu
Synu!

"Son in Warsaw" simply would *not* be "synowi" - it would make zero sense.
@Andrzej Came to say the same. Bad editing.

@Andrzej no disrespect to them (I am English) but most Americans have no Latin, other than probably CARPE DIEM. And for the purposes of this clue, that was fine. I initially had DIES, but from the context it became clear that another form of the noun was expected. 

No matter how you slice it, DIEM is still Latin for ‚Äúday‚Äù. It‚Äôs just one of those contextual clues, like, say:

7. Federal loan program

which could solve either to FANNIE MAE or FANNIE MAC, depending on the other words. 

I get your point, but find it persnickety. I think it‚Äôs fair, and I don‚Äôt doubt for a second that you had no difficulty getting it.

@Andrzej 

Regarding the declension thingie ‚Äî I have noticed from time to time that too much knowledge can become an obstacle to arriving at the answer the puzzle is looking for.

@Jaze 

I see your point, but please consider mine. I speak perfect Polish and very good English Soni have expertise to evaluate this. If I encountered a clue like the one from my post above: "Son in Warsaw," I would simply never, ever accept anything else than "syn" as an answer. Perhaps because declension is not a thing in English (any more) you don't see just how absurdly wrong it is to require anything else than the nominative case as an answer to a simple clue like that. "Synowi" is *not* "son" in Warsaw. 

I get the "Carpe DIEM!" thing, I really do. So why not clue DIEM correctly? "Day seized in Ancient Rome" - there we go. It's still slightly iffy, but not blatantly wrong when you actually know declension.

That's why I'm blaming the editors. Why provide a bad clue when there are better options? I just don't get this. When I'm doing my job, I try to avoid mistakes, and nobody defends the ones I do make - and nobody should.

@Andrzej 

As one of those Americans who ‚Äúhas no Latin‚Äù, I not only know carpe DIEM, but also per DIEM and Dies Irae (probably from crosswords). Plus a knowledge of a few languages that derive from Latin, and awareness that it has declensions. 

When I got to that clue, I assumed it was going to be DIES, and was a bit surprised that it was DIEM. But not outraged like you. 

I realized that DIES would probably be clued as the actual English word that it also is. You know, ‚ÄúStops working‚Äù or such.

Andrzej,

The flag was officially changed only six days ago, so at the time the puzzle was edited, the clue was correct.

Nevertheless, I think a last minute change from "has" to "had" could have been made.

@Steve L 

I'm not outraged, I'm just puzzled why such a badly conceived clue was chosen when better options were available. I keep thinking about things like Warszawie (rather than the nominative Warszawa) being clued as capital of Polska. No, just no. It's 100% wrong and one simply can't justify it. Would you accept Mufasa's (rather than Mufasa) as the name of, oh I don't know, a lion, or a Turk, maybe? DIEM is equally wrong clued as simply "day" (for Warsaw, that would be Warszawy, rather than Warszawa, and it would be wrong, too, on all possible levels).

@Barry Ancona

@Andrze
I get you, I really do. But I would say is that the reason it‚Äôs ok is because English has no declension here. DIES translates to DAY just like DIEM does. One could create a more unambiguous clue but then DIEM would always have to be clued as some form of carpe DIEM. I don‚Äôt think the clue implied the nominative case. In contrast, if the clue was ‚ÄúHe in France‚Äù and the answer was LUI that would be wrong, because we do have a declension in English and LUI can only be translated to HIM.

@Charlie for iOS press the more on the bottom left of the keyboard and then when the keyboard switches to number format, press Rebus on the bottom right. Hope that helps.

@Charlie in the appropriate square, press More (lower left), then Rebus (lower right). The square changes a bit with a yellow border. Now type in whatever you want there (word, numbers, anything on the keyboard). Then either arrow out (used to move to the next clue) or tap somewhere else to get out of this cell. Voil√†, a rebus. If you made a mistake, highlight that cell again and press backspace (delete) button.

@Charlie The puzzle will accept just the first letter of a rebus. Once the whole puzzle is solved, you can‚Äôt modify it. Next time you‚Äôll be ready!

If you suspect your last square is a rebus, delete some other square, enter the rebus, then go back and fix the other square.

@Charlie if the timer has stopped, the puzzle is solved and you can't make changes. For this rebus square the single letter "S" is an accepted alternate, so if you e entered that it would be valid to solve the puzzle.

@JonathanT - I believe this is an intentional aspect of the Mini‚Äôs construction, since it has been there from the beginning.

@Topher 

So (unless you're being purposely provocative) this might be the first "rebus" puzzle you've encountered.  They're pretty common here.  Many of us hate / tolerate them but they're a thing.  This one was terrific.  :)

@Topher The rules have not changed. Rebuses have been present in NYT crosswords almost since the beginning. See: https://www.nytimes.com/article/how-to-solve-a-crossword-puzzle.html Specifically the section on how to enter more than one letter in a square.
@Topher, no rules were broken in the making (or solving) of this absolutely delightful puzzle.
@Puzzled that is always how it works

@Puzzled 

To explain: The first letter of a rebus is usually accepted as a substitute for the rebus entry per long-standing convention. You might see the occasional comment (there was one at the beginning of today's comments) about someone regretting  accidentally having filled in the rebus square with an appropriate letter and solving the puzzle without having entered the actual rebus.
@Puzzled It‚Äôs not right, but it is standard. That said, it should have accepted just a * in that square today.

San Jose is located within the Santa Clara Valley, in the southern part of the Bay Area in Northern California. The northernmost portion of San Jose touches San Francisco Bay at Alviso, though most of the city lies away from the bayshore.

@Lewis 

I know, but that usage is old and not used anymore.  While technically correct since it's in a dictionary, I think if you included a robin in a theme that related to fowl, crying foul would be justified.

@Jill  I'm rather new to crosswords also, and before I got a subscription I used to look up the puzzles in an already-solved view and just read the clues and answers. I think I learned a lot that way, whether I liked the clues or not.  I did go to another publication to solve their puzzles bc it was free. I did that for 2 or 3 months then got my subscription to the NYT. I'm not yet a month into my subscription and can now solve Mondays - Wednesdays with relative ease (just a few lookups). And I like being challenged on the other days. You can go to the archives if you want to try more Monday ones.

I actually learn alot from the comments here, especially from the more seasoned folks. More than once, I learned something that eventually helped me on another puzzle. The comments are entertaining too, sometimes! üòÜ

@Jill, I prefer the moniker "experienced solver"!

Give it time. Keep reading Gameplay. (We old fogies didn't have that fabulous resource; we simply failed, and waited for the next day (or the next week, for Sunday puzzles) to see the answer key and try to work it backwards!)

Tackle one day at a time. Learn the "rules" and conventions, many of which are fluid and flexible.

For me, half the fun is never knowing what the daily puzzle will bring. Today's was an absolute delight, IMO, a midweek bright spot. After decades of solving, I still have a bit of existential dread when I open the Thursday puzzle, but I soldier on.
